trans-unit.source: Represents the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView"></xref> for collections that implement <xref href="System.ComponentModel.IBindingList"></xref>, such as Microsoft ActiveX Data Objects (ADO) data views.
All collections have a default <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView>.

For collections that implement <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> or <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList>, the default collection view is <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView>.

Specifically, <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> is required for <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView>, and <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> is an optional interface that gives additional sorting and filtering support.
If you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently.

For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected.
This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.
For more information about collection views, see [Data Binding Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/data/data-binding-overview.md).
Initializes an instance of <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView"></xref> over the given list.
The underlying <xref href="System.ComponentModel.IBindingList"></xref>.
Starts an add transaction and returns the pending new item.
Calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.AddNew%2A> begins an add transaction.
You should call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelNew%2A> to end the add transaction.
A new item always appears in the collection view.
Any filtering, sorting, or grouping that is applied to the view is applied to the new item when <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> is called.
The pending new item.
Gets a value that indicates whether a new item can be added to the collection.

The <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> can create a new item for the collection if there is not an edit transaction occurring, if the collection is not a fixed size, and if the collection is not read-only.
`true` if a new item can be added to the collection; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the collection view can discard pending changes and restore the original values of an edited object.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `true` if the edited item implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IEditableObject?displayProperty=fullName> interface.

If <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `false`, call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> to cause the view to exit the edit state and provide logic to revert the changes on the object that was edited.
`true` if the collection view can discard pending changes and restore the original values of an edited object; otherwise, `false`.
Ends the edit transaction and, if possible, restores the original value to the item.

<xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> sets <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CurrentEditItem%2A> to `null` and causes the collection view to exit the edit state.

If <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCancelEdit%2A> is `true`, <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A> also restores the original values of the edited object.
Ends the add transaction and discards the pending new item.
Gets a value that indicates whether this view supports turning filtering data in real time on or off.
`false` in all cases.
Gets a value that indicates whether this view supports turning grouping data in real time on or off.
`True` in all cases.
Gets a value that indicates whether this view supports turning sorting data in real time on or off.
`false` in all cases.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports custom filtering.
Use this property to test whether the view supports custom filtering before assigning a filter string to <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CustomFilter%2A>.
`true` if the view supports custom filtering; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports callback-based filtering.
<xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> does not support callback-based filtering, use <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CustomFilter%2A> instead.
This property always returns `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the view supports grouping.
For a default instance of <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView"></xref> this property always returns `true`.
Gets a value that indicates whether an item can be removed from the collection.
The <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> can remove an item if there is not an add or edit transaction occurring, and if the collection is not a fixed size or read-only.
`true` if an item can be removed from the collection; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether the collection supports sorting.
For a default instance of <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView"></xref> this property always returns `true`.
Ends the edit transaction and saves the pending changes.
Ends the add transaction and saves the pending new item.

Any filtering, sorting, or grouping that is applied to the <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> is applied to the new item when <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> is called.
Returns a value that indicates whether a given item belongs to the collection view.
This method does not make any assumptions about whether the item belongs to the underlying collection.
If you know that the item belongs to the underlying collection, it is more efficient to call <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.PassesFilter%2A>.
The object to check.
`true` if the item belongs to the collection view; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the estimated number of records in the collection.
Note that this count represents the filtered count.
One of the following:
Value
Meaning
Could not determine the count of the collection.

This might be returned by a "virtualizing" view, where the view deliberately does not account for all items in the underlying collection because the view is attempting to increase efficiency and minimize dependence on always having the entire collection available.
any other integer
The count of the collection.
Gets the item that is being added during the current add transaction.
The item that is being added if <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.IsAddingNew"></xref> is `true`; otherwise, `null`.
Gets the item in the collection that is being edited.
The item in the collection that is being edited if <xref href="System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.IsEditingItem"></xref> is `true`; otherwise, `null`.
Gets or sets a custom filter.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.CanCustomFilter%2A> property to test whether the view supports custom filtering before assigning a string to this property.
The syntax depends on the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingListView> implementation.
For an example of the supported filter expression syntax, see <xref:System.Data.DataView.RowFilter%2A>.

Note that if you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently.

For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected.
This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.
A string that specifies how the items are filtered.
Detaches the underlying collection from this collection view to enable the collection view to be garbage collected.
Begins an edit transaction of the specified item.
The item to edit.
Retrieves the item at the specified position in the view.
This method evaluates the index with any <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> properties that are set on the view.
The zero-based index at which the item is located.
The item at the specified position in the view.
If index is out of range.
Gets or sets a delegate to select the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription"></xref> as a function of the parent group and its level.
A method that provides the logic for the selection of the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription"></xref> as a function of the parent group and its level.
The default is `null`.
Gets a collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription"></xref> objects that describe how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.
This property can only be set by accessing the collection object and using its various methods such as Add.
The property to access the collection object itself is read-only; the collection itself is read/write.
A collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription"></xref> objects that describe how the items in the collection are grouped in the view.
Gets the top-level groups.
The items in the collection are of type <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewGroup>.
A read-only collection of the top-level groups, or `null` if there are no groups.
Returns the index at which the given item belongs in the collection view.
This method evaluates the index with any <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.SortDescriptions%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.Filter%2A> properties that are set on the view.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.IndexOf%2A>.
The object to look for in the collection.
The index of the item in the collection, or -1 if the item does not exist in the collection view.
Gets a value that indicates whether an add transaction is in progress.

You begin an add transaction by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.AddNew%2A> method, and you end the add transaction by calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CommitNew%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CancelNew%2A>.
`true` if an add transaction is in progress; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the list of items (after applying the sort and filters, if any) is already in the correct order for grouping.
Setting this property to `true` informs the view that the list of items is already in the correct order for grouping and allows the view to use a more efficient algorithm to build the groups.
The data is in the correct order if:
All items belonging to a given group appear consecutively, and

If the <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A> collection is non-empty, the groups in <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A> appear before any other groups, and in the same order as in <xref:System.ComponentModel.GroupDescription.GroupNames%2A>.
`true` if the list of items is already in the correct order for grouping; otherwise, `false`.
Gets a value that indicates whether an edit transaction is in progress.

You begin an edit transaction by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.EditItem%2A> method, and you end the transaction by calling <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CommitEdit%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Data.ListCollectionView.CancelEdit%2A>.
`true` if an edit transaction is in progress; otherwise, `false`.
Returns a value that indicates whether the resulting (filtered) view is empty.
`true` if the resulting view is empty; otherwise, `false`.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether filtering data in real time is enabled.
`true` if filtering data in real time is enabled; `false` if live filtering is not enabled; `null` if it cannot be determined whether the collection view implements live filtering.
<xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.IsLiveFiltering"></xref> cannot be set.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether grouping data in real time is enabled.
`true` if grouping data in real time is enabled; `false` if live grouping is not enabled; `null` if it cannot be determined whether the collection view implements live grouping.
<xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.IsLiveGrouping"></xref> cannot be set to `null`.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether sorting data in real time is enabled.
`true` if sorting data in real time is enabled; `false` if live sorting is not enabled; `null` if it cannot be determined whether the collection view implements live sorting.
<xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.IsLiveSorting"></xref> cannot be set.
Gets a collection of objects that describes the properties of the items in the collection.
A collection of objects that describes the properties of the items in the collection.
Gets a collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in filtering data in real time.
A collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in filtering data in real time.
Gets a collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in grouping data in real time.
A collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in grouping data in real time.
Gets a collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in sorting data in real time.
A collection of strings that specify the properties that participate in sorting data in real time.
Sets the item at the specified index to be the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> in the view.
The index to set the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> to.
`true` if the resulting <xref href="System.Windows.Data.CollectionView.CurrentItem"></xref> is an item within the view; otherwise, `false`.
Thrown if the index is out of range.
Gets or sets the position of the new item placeholder in the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView"></xref>.
One of the enumeration values that specifies the position of the new item placeholder in the <xref href="System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView"></xref>.
Returns a value that indicates whether the specified item in the underlying collection belongs to the view.
Unlike the <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.Contains%2A> method, this method assumes that the specified item belongs to the underlying collection.
This method takes filters into account.
Typically, you use this method during collection-changed notifications to determine if the added or removed item requires processing.
The item to check.
`true` if the specified item belongs to the view or if there is not filter set on the collection view; otherwise, `false`.
Removes the specified item from the collection.
If `item` is not in the collection, <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView.Remove%2A> does nothing.
The item to remove.
Removes the item at the specified position from the collection.
`index` is relative to the collection view, not the collection.
For example, if the collection has 10 items and the view has a <xref:System.ComponentModel.ICollectionView.Filter%2A> so that 7 items appear, the valid values of `index` are 0 through 6.
The zero-based index of the item to remove.
index is less than 0 or greater than the number of items in the collection view.
Gets a collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.SortDescription"></xref> objects that describes how the items in the collection are sorted in the view.

Note that if you have multiple <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects and the underlying source is a `DataTable` or a `DataView`, the view objects do not sort or filter independently.

For example, if you have two <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects associated with the same `DataTable` and you perform sorting on one of the views, the order of items in the other view can be affected.
This is because <xref:System.Windows.Data.BindingListCollectionView> objects use the underlying <xref:System.ComponentModel.IBindingList> for sorting and filtering functionalities.
This property can only be set by accessing the collection object and using its various methods such as `Add`.
The property to access the collection object itself is read-only; the collection itself is read/write.
A collection of <xref href="System.ComponentModel.SortDescription"></xref> objects that describe how the items in the collection are sorted in the view.
This member supports the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/includes/tlasharptla-winclient-md.md)] infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
First object to compare.
Second object to compare.
Less than zero means o1 is less than o2, a value of zero means they are equal, and over zero means o1 is greater than o2.
